text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Royal Dutch Airlines/KLM buys back 17 pct of its shares from the State. (p1)
- Dutch Enterprise Chamber blocks ABN Amro bank's plans to make its new call centre in Nijmegen independent. (p1)
- Industrial group Begemann's claim, Begaclaim, complicates planned distribution of bourse's assets. (p1)
- Dutch delegation is pessimistic about Dutch contribution to World Trade Organisation conference, starting Monday. (p1)
- Publisher Reed-Elsevier is upbeat about its 1996 earnings, but warns that strong sterling could pressure earnings by four percent. (p3)
- Building trade has better order position than last year. (p4)
- Dutch economy will end the year with 2.7 pct GDP growth according to provisional central planning bureau forecast. (p5)
- Invested assets of Dutch pension funds and seven largest insurers increase by Dfl 90 bn to Dfl 864 bn. (p11)
VOLKSKRANT
- Sport 7 shareholders' acceptance of TV station SBS 6's bid for all its football rights will mean the end for the loss- making sports-channel. (p1)
- Sale of newspaper Het Financieele Dagblad to British concern Pearson falls through due to staff opposition. (p2)
- Privatisation of automation company Roccade slowed down by row over conditions of sale between state and the company. (p2)
- PTT Telecom to dismantle its Greenpoint-Network. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Confusion among temp workers and temp agencies' clients about method of payment. (p1)
- KLM earned money from fleeing nazis after the war, says U.S. senator Alphonse d'Amato. (p1)
- Trading company Hagemeyer to take its Asian trading house HCL to Asian bourse. (p27)
- Growth of small engineering businesses is slowing down. (p29)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Smiths Food Group to restructure its crisps plant in Broek of Langedijk. (p16)
- DIY-group Intergamma is near completing the takeover of rival Wickes Benelux from Britain's Wickes. (p13)
TROUW
- Green party in parliament wants research into the future of aviation in the Netherlands. (p1)
